/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Checking the patch commit message, when a port is declared UP in the NB (LSP up) "all OVS flows corresponding to the logical port and underlying OVS interface have been installed". This exactly what we need in Neutron to declare this port as UP.

I would point to the issues we currently have in the OVN live migration, when the OF rules are still not set in the OVS and we plug the VM TAP device. The VM starts sending traffic that is incorrectly processed.

I don't think we need to save time but be sure the port Neutron declares as UP has the corresponding OF rules set in OVS and is ready, from the backend point of view, to be used.

@Rodolfo, what this patch is doing is saving the time that it takes for northd to translate the same info from SB to NB. Instead of looking into the NB database, this patch is getting the same info from the SB, hence shortcutting northd (a bottleneck at high churn), then saving time.

@Rodolfo, besides what Daniel mention about this just saving time to set the port to ACTIVE (but without changing the behavior, if the behavior is changing that means I missed something), if the UP row is present in the OVN SB schema (Port Binding table), this patch ensures the port is only transitioned to ACTIVE once the OF rules are set. That said, unless the OVN SB scheme is changed/updated prior to the OVN live migration, the old behavior (just checking the port has a chassis) will be used, not ensuring if OF rules are set.

This is not exactly what I read from the commit message:
"This allows us to delay setting the Logical_Switch_Port.up field until all OVS flows corresponding to the logical port and underlying OVS interface have been installed." The LSP is in the NB.

However this is in the patch: [1]. Thus you are right: when the SB port binding is set to UP, that means the OF rules are in place.

I'll remove my -1 and review that patch.

[1]https://github.com/ovn-org/ovn/commit/4d3cb42b076bb58fd8f01ab8ad146ffd539f2152#diff-31fb5e479b4a6ea83383e5d76c4644df6e8ab6b02a5c1086e178e90f04c5749eR2774-R2781

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
Cool! Thanks Luis++
Some comments, please check them out
Found out an issue not transitioning the newly created router ports to ACTIVE
Patch looks Ok. Thanks for the comments about how to handle compatibility with older versions. Once we can enforce 21.03.0, we'll be able to remove those extra checks.

neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/ovn/mech_dri.message: Can you please state which one is the min version that includes this column in the schema?

I think this is wrong. The port is set to up when openflow rules are installed on the chassis while chassis is set when port is claimed by ovn-controller. Those are 2 different scenarios so with this code we could set the Neutron port UP when the data plane is not ready yet.

Yep, if there is a chassis the the up column is used (same for this code, right? or am I missing something?).

But if there is no up column, it just set up to true, right? 
if (sb->chassis) {
            up = smap_get_bool(&sb->chassis->other_config,
                               OVN_FEATURE_PORT_UP_NOTIF, false)
                 ? sb->n_up && sb->up[0]
                 : true;

I understand there that if there is no need to use the OVN_FREATURE_PORT_UP_NOTIF (aka, we have the UP column), then we set up to the value of "sb->n_up && sb->up[0]", but if there is no UP column, then up is directly set to true (so, only having the chassis is what sets it to true in the case of no UP column, which is what the code here attempts to do

Idea here is that if OVN is recent enough, we will use the UP field. But if it is not new enough (and there is no UP field) we will fall back to use the chassis as the indicator. It seems the NB DB is updating lsp to up based on that information anyway (I know this is crazy old but it is the best reference I found for what I thought is the current behavior: https://github.com/ovn-org/ovn/commit/b3d3484ac13f81e89d3685d27083347e9943820d).

Based on this northd code (https://github.com/ovn-org/ovn/blob/main/northd/northd.c#L15139-L15149), I understand the NB DB is updated with status up if:
- the port is a router port
- the sb entry has a chassis

I think the condition is that "if there is a chassis then NB LSP is set to whatever is in the port binding - sb->n_up && sb->up[0]". That means if ovn-controller hasn't finished implementing openflows yet and the port_binding up column is false, the NB LSP up column will also be set to false even if chassis is set.
This is exactly like L395, maybe write a method to avoid duplication?

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
> I want to say this is on purpose as we may not have public access from some nodes.

Not intentional, purely not understood properly.

As explained by Takashi www_authenticate_uri is sent back by the middleware to the API caller ( i.e client) when there is no auth token in the request header (and auth_url is used  to validate the token). Clients always use public endpoint to authenticate.

I think this patch is taking the puppet parameter description too literally, and I suspect the author who originally wrote the comment didn't mean for it to be interpreted this way. It doesn't make sense to have services *not* using the internal API network.

I don't think the code should be forced to match an unfortunately worded comment. And I also don't think it's worth the trouble to update the comment in a large number of puppet modules unless the comment is confusing a lot of users.
I want to say this is on purpose as we may not have public access from some nodes. Are we sure we have to do this?

That is correct.

Just a side note:
s3_token middleware has the same www_authenticate_uri parameter(and the deprecated auth_uri parameter) but in this case these uri are used to contact Keystone API, and are not used in 401 responses, so this change doesn't touch that.
https://bugs.launchpad.net/tripleo/+bug/1955508 will need to be fixed before this can land

OK, I think I understand. Services will use the auth_url to contact keystone via the internal API network. www_authenticate_uri is only used if a 401 response has to be returned, in which case it makes sense to specify the public interface.

Is my understanding correct?
The error was due to the configuration of the NTP server, it can not be reached as Alex commented.
www_authenticate_uri is included in response header when 401 is returned from Keystone. It is used not by keystonemiddleware but by client. We should not expose internal url to client.

The usage of public endpoint is mentioned not only in puppet-keystone but also in keystonemiddleware itself. The description in puppet-keystone just follow the one in keystonemiddleware.

Also, as I mentioned in my reply to Alex, the url set to this parameter is exposed to client. We should not use any internal thing.

-----

diff --git a/designate/central/service.py b/designate/central/service.py
index 4d504be5..bcca87f9 100644
--- a/designate/central/service.py
+++ b/designate/central/service.py
@@ -489,11 +489,9 @@ class Service(service.RPCService):
         """
 
         # Increment the serial number
-        zone.serial = utils.increment_serial(zone.serial)
         if set_delayed_notify:
             zone.delayed_notify = True
-
-        zone = self.storage.update_zone(context, zone)
+        zone.serial = self.storage.increment_serial(context, zone)
 
         # Update SOA record
         self._update_soa(context, zone)


-----

With this patch applied I then tested creating, deleting and updating tons of records concurrently via terraform with no apparent issues anymore - no missing records, no leftovers on deletions.

I think this is fine, but our certs people (Jerry, Andy, Greg) might disagree so I added them as well
I will remove the +2 for now until we determine what the final solution will be, based on the other comments

I will try forcing wsrep_cluster_name to one of:

            X509v3 Subject Alternative Name: critical                                                                                                 
                DNS:mariadb, DNS:mariadb.openstack, DNS:mariadb.openstack.svc.cluster.local

So it turns out that GaleraDB SST is weird and we either disable `tls-server-verification` for clients or the server must have a `localhost` SAN. I have chosen the latter option as it is less of an security issue.

Additionally I enabled full SST encryption and provided an example of value override for mariadb-tls.

This seems fine to me.
Andy,Jerry and Bob all looked like they approved so I will merge.

ansible/group_vars/all.yml.message: This should be dropped and all occurences replaced by normal keystone 5000 port.
This patch is doing everything except keystone.

And reason ? admin port is not used in keystone for several releases.
Removed in train [1].

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/keystone/+/664246

So, I am asking, why not remove admin endpoint everywhere ?

Yes, keystone is special because heat still depends on an admin endpoint there, see also the devstack patches https://review.opendev.org/q/topic:%22remove-keystone-admin-endpoint%22+(status:open%20OR%20status:merged)

We could change the admin endpoint to point to the internal URL, but I'd do that in a follow-up patch.
The reason is "one thing at a time". The golden rule to deliver stuff.
This should be also dropped and all occurences replaced by normal keystone 5000 port.

openstackclient/compute/v2/server.py.message: Don't forget to remove commented out code

As discussed on Slack, this is effectively the legacy way of doing what we're doing below. You can do this, but it should only be done when the server doesn't support API microversion 2.44 or later. From 2.44 onwards, the API behind this call has been removed [1].

The logic would probably look something like:

    if not sdk_utils.supports_microversion(compute_client, '2.44'):
        # do legacy thing (add_fixed_ip_to_server)
    else:
        # do modern thing (create_server_interface)

Alternatively, you can just say that these servers are hopelessly old and we don't support them and just 'create_server_interface'. Your call.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/compute/?expanded=add-associate-fixed-ip-addfixedip-action-deprecated-detail#add-associate-fixed-ip-addfixedip-action-deprecated

Note that you want to keep using this since we need someway to convert a network name to a network ID. However, you should use the one from the *network* client. If you search for 'find_network', you'll find plenty of examples for this.
Oh, weird: the help string for the option says 2.52 but the check below is for 2.49. I wonder which one is correct?
